paper_abstract: The authors examine the relationship between security, area, and efficiency in several novel memory architectures and quantitatively examine the resulting systems through cryptographic analysis and microarchitectural impact. They discover an efficient scheme in which, even if an attacker can inspect a stored bit's value with a probabilistic error of only 5 percent, the system can prevent that adversary from learning any information about the original uncoded bits with 99.9999999999 percent probability.
